Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Undergraduate Program in Engineering Research at Berkeley (SUPERB): Collecting and Using Big Data for the Public Good

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
It is evident to all of us that the widespread and growing availability of vast amounts of real-time data presents both a tremendous opportunity to improve our understanding of the world and make better automated decisions, as well as a great technical challenge to collect, communicate and process this data efficiently and reliably. Leading researchers in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science will mentor undergraduate students on their proposed REU projects. Potential impacts range from more efficient sensor networks, to improved wireless access to the data they produce, to better human robot interaction, to better analysis of medical data from microscopes, and even helping prevent nuclear war. The project seeks to address a multitude of societal problems that can be examined by collecting and using big data while inspiring students to dedicate themselves to this work. The project is committed to exposing a diverse group of undergraduate researchers that will expand the impact of this project and the engineering research pipeline. At the conclusion of the program, participants will be proficient in using big data to solve societal problems that have direct impacts on their communities.

The goal of the Summer Undergraduate Engineering Research project in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences Department is to prepare and motivate a group of diverse competitive candidates for graduate student. The focus of the REU site is electrical engineering and computer science to support collecting and using big date for the public good. Students spend nine weeks during the summer working on high caliber research projects addressing technical challenges arising in collecting, communicating and processing the vast amounts of data becoming available both efficiently and reliably. This project covers the entire range of challenges and opportunities, from better sensor networks to collect this data more efficiently; to improved wireless resource management to move the data; to machine learning techniques for processing the images, including from microscopes, that make up much of the new data; to designing robots that can learn to interact better with humans based on the data they collect; to better enforcement of the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty by analyzing seismic data used to detect underground nuclear tests. The project will have research contributions in areas such as communications and networking, human computer interaction, machine learning, robotics, scientific computing and visualization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Summer Undergraduate Program in Engineering Research at Berkeley (SUPERB) - Collecting and Using Big Data for the Public Good program in the Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences (EECS) Department at the University of California, Berkeley (UCB) was to prepare and motivate a group of diverse, competitive candidates for graduate study. The grant?s research focus was chosen due to the widespread and growing availability of vast amounts of real-time data, presenting both a tremendous opportunity to improve our understanding of the world and make better automated decisions, as well as a great technical challenge to collect, communicate and process this data efficiently and reliably.

 

Over the duration of the three year grant, each summer 8 SUPERB students spent 9 weeks at UC Berkeley working on high caliber research projects addressing technical challenges arising in collecting, communicating and processing the vast amounts of data becoming available both efficiently and reliably.  The 24 SUPERB students who participated in this grant have conducted unique research in areas across electrical engineering and computer science, worked closely with a graduate mentor and a faculty mentor, and attended many professional development seminars aimed at applying to graduate school. Individual application workshops between each SUPERB participant and program coordinator were offered to personally assist each student with their materials for graduate school.  SUPERB students produced posters of their work which they presented to the EECS community at UCB, and also gave technical talks to the individual research groups and to the broader EECS community. Students from each of the three cohorts were selected to present their research at conferences after the conclusion of their SUPERB summer programs. 100% of the participants from the three cohorts successfully completed the program.

 

SUPERB provided training in conducting research, framing a problem, exposure to different methods of solving technical problems, acquisition of new computer languages, and practice in making oral presentations. Graduate student mentors were provided training in mentoring prior to the summer and were invited to all the student weekly meetings. All SUPERB students were required to present it to the EECS community, and also to create and present a technical poster of their work. Training in putting together these presentations was provided by faculty and graduate mentors, administrative staff, and through regular group meetings with SUPERB students.

 

SUPERB regularly integrated various parts of the program with other large REU programs active within EECS and the College of Engineering at UCB.  Although the research areas were somewhat different, the goals of the projects had much in common with those of the SUPERB program, which was to expose talented undergraduates to research and provide preparation for graduate school. For the three years of the grant, we had a successful partnership with the Center for Energy Efficient Electronics Science (E3S) also at UCB. Students from the

programs indicated that this partnership greatly enhanced the SUPERB REU experience. Students indicated that the partnership provided them an opportunity to connect with undergraduate and graduate students in majors that they may not have otherwise had the opportunity to interact with. In addition to broadening their understanding of their own

research, they also were able to comprehend how their research in electrical engineering and computer science might be aligned with other engineering disciplines. For instance, the E3S program REU students were primarily mechanical and electrical engineering students.

 

The EECS SUPERB Collecting and Using Big Data for the Public Good REU program recruited a diverse group of 8 rising juniors and seniors per summer who are citizens and permanent residents of the United States. Over the three years of the grant the number of applications steadily increased. In 2017 there were 145 applications and in 2019 there were 285 applications.  Overall, during the three years of the grant, 54% of participants were female and 42% underrepresented minority. The program achieved its goal of providing enriching research opportunities to students who may not otherwise have had them available.
